title: Pork, celery and water chestnut wontons with ma la chilli oil
description: This recipe was created by Ching-He Huang as part of a traditional Chinese New Year menu. She’s filled wonton wrappers with a fabulously tasty pork and water chestnut filling and drizzled them in a homemade ma la chilli oil. Divine.
ingredients: 1 medium free-range egg, beaten (plus another, beaten, to seal)
300g minced British free-range pork belly (if you’re buying pre-packed, look for mince with a higher fat content)
50g tinned water chestnuts, drained and finely chopped
2 tbsp premium reduced-sodium light soy sauce
2 tsp shaoxing rice wine or dry sherry
36 wonton egg wrappers (7.5cm squares; available from Asian supermarkets or online at theasiancookshop.co.uk)
1 tsp sichuan peppercorns, toasted in a dry pan and ground
1 tbsp premium reduced-sodium light soy sauce
1 small handful of coriander, roughly chopped

method.Step 1: For the chilli oil, heat the rapeseed oil in a wok or small pan over a medium heat. Add the chilli flakes and the sichuan pepper and stir to combine. Cook over a medium heat for 1-2 minutes, being careful not to let the chilli flakes burn. Pour into a heatproof bowl. Stir in the black rice vinegar, soy sauce, sesame oil and a pinch of fine salt, then set aside to cool (see Make Ahead).

method.Step 2: In a large bowl, mix together all the ingredients for the dumpling filling except the wrappers and the beaten egg to seal (see food team’s tips).

method.Step 3: To make the wontons, lay out the wrappers in batches on a clean work surface. Put roughly 1½ tsp filling in the middle of each. Brush the edges of the wrapper with a little beaten egg, then gather them up and mould around the filling into a ball shape, twisting at the top to secure the dumpling. Repeat with the remaining wrappers. Set aside 4 wontons per person and freeze any unused dumplings (see Make Ahead).

method.Step 4: Bring a large, wide pan of water to the boil, then turn the heat down to a simmer. Using a slotted spoon, gently lower in the dumplings in batches and simmer gently for 4-5 minutes or until they float to the surface and turn a translucent yellow (see Ching’s tip). Cut a dumpling open to check the fillingis cooked. Using the slotted spoon, transfer the dumplings to a serving platter or 4 individual bowls. Spoon over a little dumpling cooking water to stop them drying out, then drizzle over a little chilli oil (see food team’s tips). Garnish with the spring onions and coriander and serve.
